	                 return {};
	           }

  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/197711-elon-musk-unveils-new-plan-to-circle-to-earth-in-satellites-for-fast-low-latency-internet" rel="next" title="Elon Musk unveils new plan for global satellite internet, while Google invests a billion in SpaceX [UPDATED]"/>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/computing/197720-beyond-ddr4-understand-the-differences-between-wide-io-hbm-and-hybrid-memory-cube" rel="canonical"/>

           <a href="http://pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/jump?iu=/4585/zd.extech/computingsection_ATF&amp;t=zdid%3D197720%26cmn%3Dzd&amp;sz=970x250|728x90&amp;template=article&amp;c=2886268&amp;tile=1">

      <div class="add-nav">
       <ul class="breadcrumbs" id="breadcrumbs">
        <!-- Breadcrumb NavXT 5.1.1 -->
        <li class="home">
         <a href="http://www.extremetech.com" title="Go to ExtremeTech.">
          ExtremeTech
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span typeof="v:Breadcrumb">
          <a class="taxonomy category" href="http://www.extremetech.com/category/computing" property="v:title" rel="v:url" title="Go to the Computing category archives.">
           Computing
          </a>

        <li class="current_item">
         Beyond DDR4: The differences between Wide I/O, HBM, and Hybrid Memory Cube
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <div class="twocolumns">
       <div id="content">
        <div class="article">
         <div class="title">
          <h2>
           Beyond DDR4: The differences between Wide I/O, HBM, and Hybrid Memory Cube
          </h2>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="by vcard">
             By
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/author/jhruska" rel="author" title="Posts by Joel Hruska">
              Joel Hruska
             </a>
             on January 20, 2015 at 9:07 am
            </span>
           </li>
           <li class="comments">
            <a data-disqus-identifier="197720 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=197720" href="http://www.extremetech.com/computing/197720-beyond-ddr4-understand-the-differences-between-wide-io-hbm-and-hybrid-memory-cube#disqus_thread">
             <span>
              Comment
             </span>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div class="content">
          <span id="intelliTXT" name="intellitxt">
           <img alt="Hardware" class="attachment-full wp-post-image" height="353" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/ram-640x353.jpg" width="640"/>
           <div class="photo">
            <div class="box2">
             <h3>
              Share This article
             </h3>
             <div class="addthis_sharing_toolbox">
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            There are major changes coming in the memory interface world, and recent interest in AMD and Nvidias plans to adopt the new High Memory Bandwidth standard make this a good time to explainthe three new standards: Wide I/O, HBM, and HMC.Lets kick things off with a basic question  why do we need new memory standards in the first place?
           </p>
           <p>
            DDR4 and LPDDR4 are both
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/computing/192711-samsungs-new-20nm-ddr4-clears-the-way-for-massive-128gb-dimms">
             incremental, evolutionary improvements
            </a>
            to existing DRAM designs. As well explore in this story, both standards improve power consumption and performance relative to DDR3/LPDDR3, but theyre not a huge leap forward. Many of the underlying technologies baked into the standard were set a decade or more ago, when total system bandwidth was a fraction of current levels and CPUs were all single-core.
           </p>
           <p>
            While the standard has evolved considerably from where it began, its worth remembering that the first modern SDRAM DIMMs debuted on a 66MHz interface and provided 533MB/s of bandwidth. DDR4-3200, in contrast, is clocked at up to 1600MHz and offers up to 25.6GB/s of memory bandwidth. Thats an increase of 48x over nearly 20 years, but it also means that weve pushed the standard a very long way. While theres been debate over whether or not to define a traditional DDR5, the broad industry consensus is that new solutions are necessary.
           </p>
           <h3>
            Samsungs Wide I/O: Ultra low-power bandwidth
           </h3>
           <p>
            Wide I/O and Wide I/O 2 have been backed by companies like Samsung and are designed to provide mobile SoCs with a maximum amount of bandwidth at the lowest possible power consumption. Its a technology thats been most interesting to companies building smartphones and embedded systems, where high resolution displays have put enormous pressure on bandwidth while low power requirements are critical to battery life.
           </p>
           <div class="wp-caption alignnone" id="attachment_197722" style="width: 412px">
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/wideio2.jpg">
             <img alt="Wide IO 2" class="wp-image-197722 size-full" height="347" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/wideio2.jpg" width="402"/>
            </a>
            <p class="wp-caption-text">
             Samsungs Wide I/O 2 architecture
            </p>
           </div>
           <p>
            Wide I/O is designed specifically to stack on
            <em>
             top
            </em>
            of SoCs and use vertical interconnects to minimize electrical interference and die footprint. This optimizes the packages size, but also imposes certain thermal limitations, since heat radiated from the SoC has to pass through the entire memory die. Operating frequencies are lower, but a large number of I/O pins increases bandwidth by using a memory bus thats up to 1024 bits wide.
           </p>
           <p>
            Wide I/O is the first version of the standard, but its Wide I/O 2 thats expected to actually reach the mass market  though some have argued that true adoption wont come until Wide I/O 3, which should finally open a gap between itself and LPDDR4. The standard was ratified by JEDEC, but its often associated with Samsung due to that companys extensive work on bringing it to market. Timing is unclear, but no major devices are expected to ship with Wide I/O in the first half of 2015. We may see some limited pickup in the back half of the year, possibly from Samsungs own foundries.
           </p>
           <p>
            Wide I/O is explicitly designed to be a 3D interface, but 2.5D interposer designs are possible. Since one of the major challenges of a 3D Wide I/O structure is cooling the CPU underneath the DRAM its possible that the first chips will be 2.5D interposer designs.
           </p>
           <h3>
            Intel and Micron: Hybrid Memory Cube
           </h3>
           <p>
            In Corner #2, we have Hybrid Memory Cube, the joint
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/185007-intels-next-gen-xeon-phi-will-be-3x-faster-include-next-gen-hybrid-memory-cube-tech">
             Intel-Micron standard
            </a>
            . HMC is designed to emphasize massive amounts of bandwidth at higher power consumption and cost than Wide I/O 2. Intel and Micron have claimed that up to 400GB/s of bandwidth may be possible via HMC, with production expected in 2016 and commercial availability in 2017.
           </p>
           <p>
            HMC is not a JEDEC standard but has multiple development partners, including Samsung, Micron, Microsoft, Altera, ARM, Intel, HP, and Xilinx. One of the major goals of HMC is to strip out the duplicative control logic of modern DIMMS, simplify the design, connect the entire stack in a 3D configuration, then use a single control logic layer to handle all read/write traffic.
           </p>
           <p>
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/HMC-Slide.jpg">
             <img alt="HMC-Slide" class="alignnone wp-image-197724 size-large" height="453" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/HMC-Slide-640x453.jpg" width="640"/>
            </a>
           </p>
           <p>
            The promise of Hybrid Memory Cube is an architecture thats explicitly designed to respond to multi-core scenarios and deliver data with much higher bandwidth and lower overall latency. HMC is extremely forward looking, and it
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/computing/185797-forget-moores-law-hot-and-slow-dram-is-a-major-roadblock-to-exascale-and-beyond">
             solves a number of problems
            </a>
            related to exascale computing, but its also dependant on a number of profound improvements to semiconductor manufacturing. Its the most expensive new standard, and the only one not ratified by JEDEC.
           </p>
           <div class="wp-caption alignnone" id="attachment_197727" style="width: 650px">
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/HMC-Power.png">
             <img alt="HMC-Power" class="wp-image-197727 size-large" height="201" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/HMC-Power-640x201.png" width="640"/>
            </a>
            <p class="wp-caption-text">
             Power consumption comparison
            </p>
           </div>
           <p>
            The slide above is from 2011, but the projections appear to still be accurate. At huge scale, memory power consumption from DDR3 and DDR4 is simply too high to allow for efficient scaling. Slashing memory power consumption by two-thirds would have a huge impact on supercomputing in the 2020 timeframe.
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             Next page:
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/computing/197720-beyond-ddr4-understand-the-differences-between-wide-io-hbm-and-hybrid-memory-cube/2">
              High bandwidth memory
             </a>
            </strong>
           </p>
           <ul class="paging">
            <li class="previous">
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/computing/197720-beyond-ddr4-understand-the-differences-between-wide-io-hbm-and-hybrid-memory-cube/2">
             </a>
            </li>
            <li>
             <strong>
              1
             </strong>
             of
             <strong>
              2
             </strong>
            </li>
            <li class="next">
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/computing/197720-beyond-ddr4-understand-the-differences-between-wide-io-hbm-and-hybrid-memory-cube/2">
              Next
              <img src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/themes/extremetech/images/arrow.gif"/>
             </a>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </span>
         </div>
         <div class="articles-list">
          <div class="holder">
           <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-45">

            </div>

         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="articles-list">

          <div class="widget column widget_disquswidget" id="disquswidget-3">
           <script type="text/javascript">
            var disqus_developer = 1;
           </script>
           <div class="title">
            <span class="count">
             <a href="#disqus_thread">
              Comment
             </a>
            </span>
            <h3>
             Post a Comment
            </h3>
           </div>
           <div id="disqus_thread">
            <div id="dsq-content">
             <ul id="dsq-comments">
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-375018">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375018">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-375018">
                 http://www.sirgcal.com/
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-375018">
                  SirGCal
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375018">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375018">
                 <p>
                  Id like to see more real world HBM options, and see what it can really do even in some APU setups. However, time will tell.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375027">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375027">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-375027">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375027">
                    Joel Hruska
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375027">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375027">
                   <p>
                    I would expect HBM to give an APU a 30-50% performance improvement in &gt;35W TDP form factors. In low TDP environments, other power consumption factors are likely to dominate, but Id still expect 20-30% improvement.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Any company that builds an SoC with HBM will have to contend with the fact that youre packing even more heat into a smaller space. I think this will be the most limiting factor.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-375034">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375034">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-375034">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-375034">
                      pelov lov
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375034">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375034">
                     <p>
                      Joel, Ive got a question related to that -
                      <br/>
                      Are the TDPs on discrete GPUs including the vRAM? or is it excluded? Might explain why there are rumblings of a 300W TDP for AMDs next flagship GPU
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-375043">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375043">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-375043">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-375043">
                        Joel Hruska
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375043">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375043">
                       <p>
                        Pelov,
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Thats a very good question. Let me ask.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        UPDATE:  AMDs TDP figures for a GPU include total board power, not just the ASIC power. So a memory interface shift wouldnt impact this one way or the other.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-375112">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375112">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-375112">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-375112">
                          pelov lov
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375112">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375112">
                         <p>
                          Thanks. Puts things into perspective
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-375171">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375171">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-375171">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-375171">
                          Joel Hruska
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375171">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375171">
                         <p>
                          I would have few arguments with a 300W TDP from AMD if they pair it with a GPU cooling solution like the R9 295X2s. While I prefer low-power to high-power, Ill take high power if it still means low noise.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          But I have little and less information on what AMDs next-gen chip actually looks like.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-375265">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375265">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-375265">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-375265">
                          pelov lov
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375265">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375265">
                         <p>
                          If the performance justifies the power consumption, then it isnt a big deal. In fact, it might even be better. For example, running a 4K display at over 60FPS without requiring crossfire/SLi and the niggling troubles with either is something that would appeal to a lot of folks. I personally despise all-in-one water-cooling, but some people prefer it.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          But it might also point to AMDs next-gen GPU uArch again not being feasible for laptops and small form-factor devices; AMDs perennial plight against efficiency leading to another defeat.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Well see, I guess. After Tonga, Im not expecting much from their GPU teams either.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-375514">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375514">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-375514">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-375514">
                          Joel Hruska
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375514">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375514">
                         <p>
                          Its entirely possible that AMD has pursued a bifurcated strategy where some of these technologies are concerned. I have never attempted to isolate the GPU inside a socketed A10-7850K to see how it compares against an equivalent R7 250 or 250X and Im not sure its possible to make those measurements  the granularity may not be available without performing board modifications to measure power draw.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          AMDs APUs are being built at GlobalFoundries on 28nm and possibly Samsungs 14nm starting in 2016. Its GPUs, as far as I know, are still being built at TSMC. That means its entirely possible that the company will roll out one flavor of GCN intended for high performance and at relatively low efficiency and a second integrated GPU built on Samsungs process but designed for high efficiency.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Both of those products can be GCN and it would make sense for them to do some custom optimization work depending on use-case.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                     </ul>
                     <!-- .children -->
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>
                   <!-- .children -->
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-375064">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375064">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-375064">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-375064">
                      Phobos
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375064">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375064">
                     <p>
                      If HBM is to give APUs a 30-50% performance improvement &gt;35W TDP will that translate to just laptops or in general to desktops and laptops?
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-375068">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375068">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-375068">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-375068">
                        massau
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375068">

                       <p>
                        i think all of them. Since the bandwidth and the clock of the gpu(inside the apu) in a laptop and the desktop is relatively the same. Thus both will have a significant improvement in performance.
                       </p>

                        gooing from 1600 to 2133 ddr ram will give a performance boost.
                       </p>

              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-375020">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375020">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-375020">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-375020">
                  BtotheT
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375020">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375020">
                 <p>
                  Seems well get them all in due time, be it mobile, desktop, or servers.. Its surpising to me how many specialzed avenues are being worked on. Hopefully they devote as much effort into display effeciency/capability as well, as right now its a major efficiency/functionality bottleneck. I want a 2 watt holographic display/projection or a half watt common 1080p A leap there would mean a lot to mobile.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375159">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375159">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-375159">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375159">
                    Zunalter
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375159">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375159">
                   <p>
                    As Moores Law slows down and dies, semi companies are desperately looking for an avenue to keep it going. Barring that, the money in the future is going to be in providing specialized solutions for particular applications, so these advancements seem to be addressing both eventualities at the same time.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-375176">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375176">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-375176">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-375176">
                      BtotheT
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375176">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375176">
                     <p>
                      Itll go optical/nanocrystal/graphene ect, moores law in silicon will die, but not in computation.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-375207">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375207">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-375207">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-375207">
                        Joel Hruska
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375207">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375207">
                       <p>
                        Believe me, I wish I saw any evidence to suggest this is true.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Graphene is a huge problem. Yes, you can build it into a transistor (sort-of), but no one has figured out how to create the enormous, near-perfect boules of graphene that are required for manufacturing. We *can* do some things to create a band-gap in graphene, but we need to be able to perform those tasks at 99.999999% accuracy in order to use it as a replacement material  and that technology just isnt there. Even if we can eventually hit the perfection targets, theres no known way to make the costs line up.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Theres a misconception in tech circles that when AMD / Intel / IBM make a major tech announcement, it marks a critical discovery. Let me give some pertinent examples:
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        III-V semiconductors are being discussed for deployment in 2018-2020. They were first explored as an option nearly 30 years ago.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        FinFET transistors were proposed 20-25 years ago. The very first FinFETs were produced more than 15 years ago.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        High-k dielectrics, immersion lithography, strained silicon, carbon nanotubes, and a hundred other advances either spent 15-20 years in development *or* were theorized decades before that. Silicon photonics has been a researched phenomena for nearly 40 years.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        TL,DR version: There is no consensus in the semiconductor community about which cutting-edge, fundamental-new-approach will actually work, or any consistent belief that *any* of the current new approaches will work.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        This is a historic moment. For the first time in decades, there is no certain road forward to re-enable Moores law.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-375237">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375237">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-375237">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-375237">
                          BtotheT
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375237">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375237">
                         <p>
                          I find the concept of all-optical computing a precise matter which needs ironing but thats what I see computing to need. It took the last century to iron out and advance binary, I think we could use a new project to study and potentiate. I also find the 5D nanostructured crystals to fit into the futuristic storage imagery, tell me data crystal doesnt sound neat. Not just that but with the right precision it could be very effective at the high end server applications perhaps if they work out the right form of efficient tranmission to be the activator, could save bundles on power and heat potentially.
                          <br/>
                          Also on the graphene note, yeah its still a puzzle and very difficult to work with, but Aha!s do happen every so often, deep fried graphene of recent is a neat way of doin things. I dont believe the future to be ever adapted techologies but of new possibilities itself. I agree that no one has hit the nail on the head yet, but I trust based on past precedence that mankind will have its fateful/fortunate swing again. Nature fills the void, and one is forming.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-375294">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375294">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-375294">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-375294">
                          Joel Hruska
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375294">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375294">
                         <p>
                          Using optical connections for data transmission has the potential to dramatically reduce power consumption if we can figure out the problem.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Its not that researchers have just given up on finding solutions  just that even after a decade of knowing these problems were coming, next-gen solutions have not been found.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->

                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375065">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375065">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-375065">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375065">
                    massau
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375065">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375065">
                   <p>
                    no only a higher resolution screen will do that. But a gpu needs to become more powerful to push 4k@60Hz. The gpu is bottlenecked by the bandwidth thus these new memory standards will improve the gpu its performance.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375076">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375076">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-375076">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375076">
                    Daniel Anderson
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375076">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375076">
                   <p>
                    From early reviews and using the features of both vendors to downscale resolution (Eg halflife 2 with downscaled 8k resolution on a 1080p screen) and found the need for AA was non-existent.  But the amount of video memory  required will be significantly more compared to 1080p.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>

              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-375042">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375042">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-375042">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-375042">
                  massau
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375042">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375042">
                 <p>
                  While theres been debate over whether or not to define a traditional DDR5. i thought DDR4 is just new and isnt really adopted yet.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375044">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375044">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-375044">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375044">
                    Joel Hruska
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375044">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375044">
                   <p>
                    DDR is new, but bear in mind where these products are all going to come to market.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Wide I/O:  Tablets and phones.
                    <br/>
                    HMC:  Enterprise server, possibly high-end workstation, exascale computing.
                    <br/>
                    HBM:  GPUs, possibly some APU use.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    In other words, these are all solutions that *dont* target the traditional desktop market.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-375063">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375063">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-375063">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-375063">
                      massau
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375063">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375063">
                     <p>
                      i think the normal ddr standard is dead lpddr might stay a little longer until TSV gets relatively cheap.
                      <br/>
                      Since HMC might be socket based it could be used for an typical desktop platform if it got cheaper. otherwise we will have to buy a chip with HMB on the package and be at the merci of the manufacturer and its price / GB.  or desktops just die
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-375093">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375093">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-375093">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-375093">
                        Joel Hruska
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375093">

                        I think the conventional desktop market will hollow out into two spaces:
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        1). Ultracheap systems
                        <br/>
                        2).  High-end workstations.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-375160">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375160">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-375160">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-375160">
                          Zunalter
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375160">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375160">
                         <p>
                          So where do PC gamers go in that eventuality? High-end workstations? Or some other form factor?
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-375170">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375170">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-375170">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-375170">
                          Joel Hruska
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375170">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375170">
                         <p>
                          Mostly. Look at current chips from AMD and Intel. Intel has high-end CPUs, AMD has the better GPU on-die. Imagine a theoretical hybrid chip that combined an Intel CPU with all its advantages and an AMD GPU on the same piece of silicon (were strictly talking about a hypothetical win/win product, not an actual situation where Intel licenses a GPU from AMD).
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Now, today, an enthusiast would turn up their nose at that situation. Memory bandwidth is a major part of why.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          I dont know if you ever read this article, but check these results:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/gaming/177677-dual-graphics-dud-intel-clobbers-amds-apus-in-budget-gaming/2" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.extremetech.com/gaming/177677-dual-graphics-dud-intel-clobbers-amds-apus-in-budget-gaming/2
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Just look at the top line  the Core i3 + R7 260X. Those two chips *could* conceivably be paired in a CPU socket with a die shrink and a bit of power optimization.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So  imagine that in 3-4 years, either AMD or Intel offered an integrated solution that delivered equivalent performance in those games as we see the Core i3 + R7 260X delivering today.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          That solution would satisfy the needs of the vast majority of gamers  and HBM could make it possible.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Those gamers would be the ones buying machines in the $400  $500 range. Everybody else would still be buying the equivalent of R9 290Xs or GTX 980s, but dropping $800  $1200 on their systems.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-375191">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375191">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-375191">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-375191">
                          jdwii
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375191">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375191">
                         <p>
                          So are you saying 600-800$ rigs might go away since that is generally the sweet spot
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-375206">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375206">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-375206">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-375206">
                          Joel Hruska
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375206">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375206">
                         <p>
                          I think it could  but only because the performance youd typically get for $600-$800 today would be selling in the $400-$500 range. Obviously there will always be *some* market for a midrange system, but I think well see more clustering than is currently the case.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                     </ul>
                     <!-- .children -->
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>
                   <!-- .children -->
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-375053">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375053">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-375053">
                 http://www.ultimatexbmc.com/
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-375053">
                  Ultimatexbmc.com
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375053">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375053">
                 <p>
                  Got bored with this article  sorry to say
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375101">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375101">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-375101">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375101">
                    BigTimmay
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375101">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375101">
                   <p>
                    Not everyone is going to understand it.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375135">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375135">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-375135">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375135">
                    Techutante
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375135">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375135">
                   <p>
                    TL:DR- Theres three new kinds of RAM, one youll see in mobile devices (but will probably never touch personally), and 2 might be competing for the PC market. Of course, as a consumer rather than a large technology clearinghouse, our option is to see what flag they run up the pole, and then salute the shit out of it with a new computer. The details arent going to really matter to us, so much as the application of the final product. (In maybe 2 years, if I read that right.)
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-375205">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375205">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-375205">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-375205">
                      Joel Hruska
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375205">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375205">
                     <p>
                      I expect HMC and HBM to be complimentary, not competitive  which is to say we may see CPUs with HMC sitting next to GPUs with HBM. This is not assured, and may not happen for years, but it wouldnt surprise me if it did.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      HBM should ship in products within 18 months unless both Nvidia and AMD badly miss their previous ship targets. HMC could be 18-36 months away. Wide I/O is projected at TSMC for 18-24 months from now, but Samsung has pushed that standard hard, and so may adopt it in their own product line earlier than TSMCs roadmap indicates.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-376593">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376593">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-376593">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-376593">
                        TomRFL
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376593">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376593">
                       <p>
                        You will likely first see cpus integrated onto the gpu in conjunction with HBM.  This (and APUs) will be the early implementation of HSA in mainstream computing.  Later, when HMC arrives, I believe you will see the traditional CPU brought into the mix and yes there will be a push in discrete systems to get the GPU and CPU as close as possible to reduce latency.  I believe this, in part, because of the mention of HMC interface lanes in the slide above.  In any case, a high bandwidth, low latency path would be required in order for this type of discrete, interconnected HSA to function properly.  Whether this would be via more/higher speed PCI-E lanes or a new interface, I do not know, but this is my guess.  As you mentioned, industry is fast approaching a brick wall with silicon.  In order to get performance gains until a new alternative can be found, I expect they will change the rules a bit with current architectures.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>
                   <!-- .children -->
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-375057">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375057">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-375057">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-375057">
                  Andre Rezende
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375057">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375057">
                 <p>
                  At least a graph with silicon photonics Waiting next generation
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375090">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375090">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-375090">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375090">
                    Joel Hruska
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375090">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375090">
                   <p>
                    Silicon photonics as a memory interface is probably 7-10 years away. However, some of these techniques could be implemented *with* silicon photonics at some point in the future.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Remember, it always takes a great deal longer than companies say it will. Thunderbolt was supposed to used optical cabling for its connections but in reality, its still a copper-based signal (you can buy an optical cable for it, but youll pay hundreds of dollars).
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-375260">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375260">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-375260">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-375260">
                      witeken
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375260">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375260">
                     <p>
                      Intels DCG Diane Bryant showed silicon photonics at the Investor Meeting 2014 for commercial availability in 2015. Page 29 and 30:
                      <a href="http://intelstudios.edgesuite.net/im/2014/pdf/2014_Intel_IM_DianeBryant.pdf" rel="nofollow">
                       http://intelstudios.edgesuite.net/im/2014/pdf/2014_Intel_IM_DianeBryant.pdf
                      </a>
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-375291">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375291">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-375291">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-375291">
                        Joel Hruska
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375291">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375291">
                       <p>
                        Right. But not for memory. Shes talking about using silicon photonics for network connections. Thats an entirely different question and problem.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        IF you want to use silicon photonics instead of copper wires, you have to build nanoscale transmitters and aggregators. Its extremely difficult. IBM has demonstrated some chip-to-chip transmission capability, but no one has yet integrated that tech into a commercial product.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Silicon photonics in networking will be available long before silicon photonics on-die and integrated as a DRAM interface.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>
                   <!-- .children -->
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>

                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375460">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375460">

                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375460">
                    p. asta
                   </span>

                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375460">

                    yea, I heard that for the last 20 years
                   </p>

                 </div>

               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-375152">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375152">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-375152">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-375152">
                  Wall
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375152">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375152">
                 <p>
                  Speed doesnt matter if the cost is rediculous.  I have a hard time seeing graphics card makers cutting into there profits by using the more expensive memory
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375204">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375204">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-375204">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375204">
                    Joel Hruska
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375204">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375204">
                   <p>
                    You have to take a larger view of the industry to understand why this matters. The cost of scaling to next-generation nodes gets higher every year, while the *benefits* of those nodes get smaller.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    (Alternately, it can take longer and longer to realize the same benefits, which translates  into extended development cycles, which winds up costing more money as well).
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    So:  If adopting a next-generation memory architecture allows you to simplify other aspects of your product and improve the overall performance dramatically while dodging the bullet of simply scaling your GPU to the next-lowest process (or trying to build something even more complicated) than manufacturers are absolutely going to go that route.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-375246">

               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375246">

                  I got a feeling hUMA and HBM will saves AMDs bacon.
                 </p>
                </div>

              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-375462">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375462">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-375462">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-375462">
                  p. asta

                  You forgot Intel MCDRAM.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375511">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375511">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-375511">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375511">
                    Joel Hruska
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375511">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375511">
                   <p>
                    MCDRAM is not an industry standard  its a specialized application of HMC developed solely for Intels Knights Landing and possible follow-up products. I didnt discuss Nvidias memory interface partnership with IBM for the same reason.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-375689">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375689">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-375689">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-375689">
                  Roger
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375689">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375689">
                 <p>
                  Never mind the bandwidths, what about the processor to memory latencies? Very wide interfaces are not so useful in general purpose computing
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-375733">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-375733">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-375733">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-375733">
                    Joel Hruska
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-375733">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-375733">
                   <p>
                    Memory latency in HBM and HMC are both much improved over previous thanks to the ability to open multiple pages independently and feed multi-threaded CPUs from separate controllers. Latency improvements are a huge focus of both standards.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Its less clear what the Wide I/O situation is, because one way to keep power consumption down on mobile hardware is to emphasize fast transitions to low power modes over high performance.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->

        config.language = '';

        /*
           All currently supported events:
            * preData  fires just before we request for initial data
            * preInit - fires after we get initial data but before we load any dependencies
            * onInit  - fires when all dependencies are resolved but before dtpl template is rendered
            * afterRender - fires when template is rendered but before we show it
            * onReady - everything is done
         */

        config.callbacks.preData.push(function() {
            // clear out the container (its filled for SEO/legacy purposes)
            document.getElementById(disqus_container_id).innerHTML = '';
        });
                config.callbacks.onReady.push(function() {
            // sync comments in the background so we don't block the page
            var script = document.createElement('script');
            script.async = true;
            script.src = '?cf_action=sync_comments&amp;post_id=197720';

            var firstScript = document.getElementsByTagName( "script" )[0];
            firstScript.parentNode.insertBefore(script, firstScript);
        });
                    };

           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">

           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">

    dsq.async = true;
    dsq.src = '//' + disqus_shortname + '.' + 'disqus.com' + '/embed.js?pname=wordpress&amp;pver=2.74';

         </div>

           var __EXTECH = __EXTECH || {};

       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-46">
        <script type="text/javascript">
         window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
    _taboola.push({flush: true});
    
    var __ZDTABEVENT = {
        accountid : "",
        init : function(acct) {
            __ZDTABEVENT.accountid = acct;
            var divs = document.querySelectorAll("div[id^=taboola]"), i=divs.length;
            while (i--) {
                divs[i].addEventListener("click", __ZDTABEVENT.clkevt);
                __ZDTABEVENT.track(divs[i].id, "imp");
            }
        },
        clkevt : function(evt){
            __ZDTABEVENT.track(evt.currentTarget.id, "clk");


        },
        track : function(id,evt) {
            var el = document.getElementById(id);
            var placement = el.getAttribute('data-placement');
            var pagetype = el.getAttribute('data-page-type');
            if(window.ga) window.ga('send', 'event', 'Taboola', pagetype + '-' + placement, evt);
            if(window._gaq) window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'Taboola', pagetype+'-'+placement, evt, undefined, true]);
            if (__ZDDMP) { __ZDDMP.Event({signal:'taboola', pubid: __ZDTABEVENT.accountid, ptype:pagetype, placement:placement, evt:evt});}
        }
    };
    __ZDTABEVENT.init('ziffdavis-network15-extremetech');
        </script>
       </div>

        <!-- chartbeat -->
        <script type="text/javascript">
         var _sf_async_config = _sf_async_config || {};
/** CONFIGURATION START **/
&lt;!-- set in head --&gt;
_sf_async_config.sections = 'Computing'; 
_sf_async_config.authors ='Joel Hruska';
/** CONFIGURATION END **/
(function(){
function loadChartbeat()
{ window._sf_endpt=(new Date()).getTime(); var e = document.createElement('script'); e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript'); e.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript'); e.setAttribute('src', '//static.chartbeat.com/js/chartbeat.js'); document.body.appendChild(e); }

var oldonload = window.onload;
window.onload = (typeof window.onload != 'function') ?
loadChartbeat : function()
{ oldonload(); loadChartbeat(); }

;
})();
        </script>

        <script type="text/javascript">
         jQuery(document).ready(function() {
  setTimeout(function() {
  if (jQuery("#adsense").height() &lt; 8) { 
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','Blocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'Blocked'); }
  } else {
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','NotBlocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'NotBlocked' ); }
    }
	}, 2000);
});
        </script>

  <!-- This website is patched against a big problem not solved from WordPress 2.5+ to date -->
  <script type="text/javascript">
   // &lt;![CDATA[
        var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
        (function () {
            var nodes = document.getElementsByTagName('span');
            for (var i = 0, url; i &lt; nodes.length; i++) {
                if (nodes[i].className.indexOf('dsq-postid') != -1) {
                    nodes[i].parentNode.setAttribute('data-disqus-identifier', nodes[i].getAttribute('rel'));
                    url = nodes[i].parentNode.href.split('#', 1);
                    if (url.length == 1) url = url[0];
                    else url = url[1]
                    nodes[i].parentNode.href = url + '#disqus_thread';
                }
            }
            var s = document.createElement('script'); s.async = true;
            s.type = 'text/javascript';
            s.src = '//' + 'disqus.com/forums/' + disqus_shortname + '/count.js';
            (document.getElementsByTagName('HEAD')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('BODY')[0]).appendChild(s);
        }());
    //]]&gt;
  </script>
  <script src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-includes/js/jquery/ui/jquery.ui.core.min.js?ver=1.10.4" type="text/javascript">
